results.title: Harry's War (A)
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Frankland, John Foss, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Victoria, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, AFI [au] and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Elizabeth
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Shekhar Kapur, Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Alison Owen and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: Elizabeth begins during the tense period before Elizabeth I became Queen of England. She is a young vivacious girl thrust suddenly into the machiavellian world of politics when she is tried for treason at the age of 21. Surviving this she becomes Queen, and the film charts the beginning of her reign as she struggles to learn the skills of a monarch. Cate Blanchett is amazing as a young woman who slowly casts off her youth and becomes the legendary Virgin Queen that ruled the Elizabethan age. Shekhar Kapur’s film manages to be both entertaining and historically insightful. Lavish costumes and an excellent cast make this compelling viewing. The cast also includes Joseph Fiennes as Elizabeth’s lover Lord Robert Dudley, Richard Attenborough as Sir William Cecil, and Geoffrey Rush as her political adviser Sir Francis Walsingham. (Awards: Cate Blanchett won the 1998 Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Drama, and “Elizabeth” won the 1998 Academy Award for Best Makeup)

results.title: Morning paper
results.creator_credit: Darrel Catling, Donald Carter, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The story of a newspaper during wartime. Shows how the news is gathered and prepared for the press in spite of the threat of bombs. Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.

results.title: Australian made
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Lowenstein, John McLean, Tom Hegarty Productions and Captured Live Productions
results.brief_description: Australian music came of age in the summer of 1987 when the cream of Oz rock swept the continent for the most ambitious series of open air concerts ever staged beneath the Southern Cross. Almost 140,000 fans in six cities were entertained with a diverse array of potent and imaginative rock - from understated avant-garde to tempestuous thunder from Down Under. The dynamic performances and behind-the-scenes activity of the tour has generated an exciting, fast paced and imaginative feature film. Includes performances by: INXS ; Jimmy Barnes ; The Triffids ; I’m Talking ; The Saints ; The Divinyls and The Models.

results.title: The Fallen idol. The Winslow boy
results.creator_credit: Oswald Hafenrichter, Graham Greene, Carol Reed, G Turney-Smith, Terence Rattigan, Anthony Asquith, Anatole de Grunwald and London Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Based on a true incident, ‘The Winslow Boy’ (produced by Anatole de Grunwald, directed by Anthony Asquith) tells the simple story of a father’s impassioned fight to clear the name of his son - a young naval cadet expelled from college after being found guilty of theft. Arthur Winslow is certain of his son’s innocence, and yet is impeded in his task to retain the boy’s honour, that is until a famous KC and political leader, Sir Robert Morton, agree to help their cause. Cast includes Robert Donat, Cedric Hardwicke and Margaret Leighton.
Based on a short story by Graham Greene, ‘The Fallen idol’ (produced and directed by Carol Reed) is a sensitive study of the way in which a young boy interprets the strange and seemingly illogical behaviour of the adults who surround him. He witnesses the adulterous relationship that develops between the butler Baines, whom he worships, and a typist at the foreign embassy in London where his father works. He also sees Baines’ wife fall to her death while spying on the couple and the boy’s interpretation of events places Baines in a perilous situation. Cast includes Michele Morgan, Ralph Richardson, Sonia Dresdel and Jack Hawkins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oswald Hafenrichter, Graham Greene, Carol Reed, G Turney-Smith, Terence Rattigan, Anthony Asquith, Anatole de Grunwald and London Film Productions

results.title: Head On
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Ana Kokkinos, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
results.brief_description: Ana Kokkinos’s debut follows the angry, confused and nihilistic 19-year-old Greek Australian, Ari (Alex Dimitriades) through 24 hours fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Bilcock, Ana Kokkinos, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
results.description:
Based on the novel Loaded by Christos Tsiolkas, Ana Kokkinos’s compelling debut feature Head On is a volatile, confronting and at times bleak look at race, sexuality and class in contemporary Australian society. The film’s lead protagonist Ari (Alex Dimitriades) is an angry, confused, nihilistic, unemployed 19-year-old Greek Australian. The film traces a particularly explosive 24 hours in his life, fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family, who he views with equal amounts of respect and contempt. Performances are excellent throughout, in particular Paul Capsis as Ari’s defiant crossdressing friend Johnny/Toula.

Cast includes Elena Mandalis, Eugenia Fragos, Julian Garner, Dora Kaskanis, Alex Papps, Damien Fotiou. Awards: Best Actor (Alex Dimitriades) and Best Supporting Actor (Paul Capsis) for the 1999 Film Critics Circle of Australia Awards.

Best Feature Film Adaptation (Andrew Bovell, Ana Kokkinos, Mira Robertson) 1998 Awgie Awards.

Best Director (Ana Kokkinos) 1999 San Francisco Lesbian and Gay Film Festival.

Best Achievement in Editing (Jill Bilcock) 1998 AFI Awards.

results.title: The Seekers: land of fury
results.creator_credit: John D Guthridge, Ken Annakin, George H. Brown and Fanfare Films
results.brief_description: This film is set in New Zealand’s early pioneering days of the 1820’s. It was a time when British settlers had to come to terms with their strange new environment and its Maori inhabitants. A group of British pioneers arrive in New Zealand with the hope for a new life down under. Philip Wayne (Jack Hawkins) and his new wife Marion (Glynis Johns), are two such pioneers. Against adverse factors, such as an earthquake, they manage to build a new settlement and garner support from the local Maori neighbours. Tensions rise when Philip becomes captivated by the wife of Chief Hongi Tepe (Inia Te Wiata), and the Maori tribes turn against the settlement in retaliation for their interracial relationship.

results.title: The Card
results.creator_credit: Clive Donner, Ronald Neame, John Bryan and British Film-Makers Limited
results.brief_description: Edward Henry Machin (Alec Guinness), Denry for short, has been determined from youth to master his own fate. He uses his powers of persuasion and deception to cajole his way to fame and fortune, but still manages to remain friends with everyone. Affectionately known as ‘The Card’, Denry’s ultimate coup occurs when he becomes the youngest mayor of his home town of Bursley. Denry is not without female companionship, and his life is influenced by three women; a Countess, a dancing teacher, and the councillor’s daughter. It is through his relationship with these women that his deceptive ways are exposed. Also starring Glynis Johns, Valerie Hobson and Petula Clark. Based on the novel by Arnold Bennett and screenplay by Eric Ambler. Also known as “The Promoter”.

results.title: A Night to remember (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Sidney Hayers, Roy Baker, William MacQuitty and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: The dramatic story of the first sailing and sinking of the ocean liner, “Titanic” in 1912. “RMS Titanic”, the liner they said was unsinkable, struck an iceberg and sank with the loss of 1500 lives. The film faithfully depicts the heroism and horror of the night the unthinkable happened. Starring Kenneth More, Laurence Naismith and David MacCallum as the radio operator. From the book by Walter Lord.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sidney Hayers, Roy Baker, William MacQuitty and Rank Film Productions

results.title: Romeo and Juliet (Luhrmann) (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Martin, Jill Bilcock, Baz Luhrmann, Gabriella Martinelli and Bazmark
results.brief_description: Baz Luhrmann, director of “Strictly Ballroom” tells the greatest love story of all time in our time. William Shakespeare’s classic tale of star-crossed lovers is set in Verona Beach; a violent modern city of guns, money and greed. In this opulent world of hate, rival gangs, and families at war Romeo and Juliet are ignited by the passion of forbidden first love and Verona Beach explodes. Shakespeare’s heart wrenching tale of doomed love is told with passion, beauty, wit and furious energy. It’s a film that will kick you in the heart.
